 As far as buying an education is concerned: if we regard "education" as having an instrumental purpose, then it's a kind of utility in which an investment (like any other investment) might never pay off.

 Regarding money buying education
 
 I agree that education should be viewed as any other good (or rather investment) and that individuals should be free to spend their money however they want. There is however one dicouraging aspect of education as an investment. Generally education is viewed as an investment in the way that it increases the students productive capabilities, and therefor results in a higher wage for the individual once the education is completed. If more money spent on education means a sharper increase of the students productive capabilities and consequently a higher wage increase, all is good and well. However, it is not certain that this view of education is correct. One could also view education as a signal system where completed education signals a highly productive individual rather than creating the excess productivity. If this signal effect is significant, one could question how much individuals (and society) should spend on education as it doesn`t create much other than competativity for the sake of competition. For the individual, it might still be profitable to invest heavily in education (in order to come out on top), but this would only encourage others to invest more, etc etc. And instead of increasing the international competativity and productive capabilities of the workforce, you end up with a bucketload of squandered resources and years wasted on internal competition.

 Ah, yes indeed. My rant got a bit one-sided. There are certainly other (very important) aspects to education than merely economics. In many ways, higher education has become more and more of a social good in the western world (for good and bad).

Is higher education (college/university) for everyone? Or should public resources (wealth/money) to educate a population be concentrated on formative years through suffrage with empathsis on high quality and future direction? While equality has a nice political sound, the fact is that many people simply don't have the intellectual capacity to benefit from college. 
 
 Before the elitist word pops up, 53% of those in the US who begin college with an objective of majoring in the arts or sciences never graduate. Of the remaining 47% who do graduate, less than 30% are awarded an undergrad degree in their chosen field. The remainder achieve a BA with little real world application. While it may be argued that those who do succeed but without obtaining skills that offer a contribution to bettering society are better educated, and I would argue that, is the public investment justified? And, considering that public resources from primary and secondary education are reallocated to facilitate college development, is reducing the quality of early education placing a restrictive burden on those not suited for higher education?  But perhaps this is the main purpose of higher education. Seperating high productive workers from low productive workers. If managing to graduate from an education signals intelectual capacity, commitment, and ability/will to work hard, higher education for everyone is not an idea of equality, but rather to usher as many as possible through this vetting process in order to make the signals more trustworthy (if everyone has been vetted, one can be more sure of the accuracy of the results).
 
 Anothe, perhaps more commonly accepted, view is that higher education is paramount for creating a "knowledge society". When the western world is unable to compete with other countries like China and India for industrial production due to high wages, one need to find a way to justify the wages economicly. By investing resources in the populace, one could hope to achieve higher productivity overall. This is in stark contrast to the theory of education as predominantly a signal tool. In order to be able to achieve this higher overall productivity, education needs to be a real investement that actually increases productivity rather than merely showing who is allready productive to begin with. I hope that the human-capital theory (as it is commonly called) is correct. But I fear that the signal theory might become more and more "accurate" for certain educations and jobs. I don`t really know how one could reverse this process though, but perhaps it would be appropriate to re-consider the government funding for certain non-productive educations in order to direct resources to those that actually makes a difference in economic/political opportunities and work-force productivity. Making it less attractive (and necessary) for students to pursue two (or three) diplomas/examinas could perhaps go a long way too...

 Public money will continue to be necessary to finance higher education in fields of utility. America (like all modern economies of course) "needs" a certain supply of engineers, computer scientists, chemists, physicists, etc., on a ongoing basis.
